content.description:
Départ dans le petit dièdre de La première valse,  pour aller rejoindre le premier relais vers la droite, à ~ 8 m du sol. Pour la deuxième longueur, suivre la dalle et passer à droite du petit toit (20 m).

Start directly in the small dihedral off La première valse and top out to the right. You will find the first belay ~ 8 m off the ground. Then follow the slab up and pass to the right of the small roof (20 m).


Trad with runout, felt PG13, but i have little experience with this.

Any crux would be at the start. From there, the climbing is really straight forward, all the stances are good. It's a classic for the area, though the climbing is not that varied. I think it's rated 5.3 by the folks at the park but the slightly more vertical nature of the second might warrant a 5.4 rating. Who knows. Start on left side of upper ledge of belay area. Gain some height on finger crack with a funky step and then follow skinny easy block system for the first half of the climb. Step right a couple feet and follow the second, more vertical, crack system with easy steps up to the top to the anchors.

Should be very obvious. Fixed anchors at the top. TR access on trail to the left.

Excellent route to learn trad techniques. Lots of placements the whole way up, maybe a little sparse for a first piece but I didn't look that hard and it starts up real quick. Excellent nut placements on the second half, easy to find and place, all stances are great.

Crux on top half. Well sustained for the grade. Crimps follow the flared crack at the start. Low angle helps a bit, varied climbing when it gets steep.

Find the vertical crack running up the middle 20-30ft of the face to meet the large horizontal crack. Right of In-between and left of L'Etonnante.
Tope rope anchors above. Can protect the first half well ( vertical crack is rounded and flared) and get good pro on the horiztonal. You are on your own from there, not much/nothing at all.

Face climbing from bottom to top. A couple small horizontals on the way. Very fun moves, lots of smears on the slab, feet switching, a fun right undercling 1/3 up, shallow pockets, nice crimps and smaller tenuous feet as the slab becomes more vertical near the crux. But they are all there! Try not to use the larger crack on the left (4/5 up) to keep it hard! In Between (ha...?) Chico (5.4) and the vertical 30 ft. crack on the right (Diabloton 5.8). Low angle face climb to high angle face, go straight up! Fixed anchors at the top.

Trad would be ballsy, but a little wandering to the left and right might protect it. First section is impossible to protect unless you use the shallow flared crack on the route to the right which would take you off route, still would be mighty funky. Maybe a cam jam on the first horizontal crack 20 ft up or so, second would be even tougher to place. Third short vertical crack is okay. Then not much till the top if I remember correctly. You might as well solo it if you think you can protect it.

Le départ est à la discretion des grimpeurs: soit dans Le Nez, soit dans L'Oubliée. Il s'agit de la dalle située en haut du petit mur vertical comportant un surplomb. The start is up to the climbers: either up Le Nez or up L'Oubliée. It's the slab above the little vertical wall that as a overhang/roof feature. Dalle située au dessus d'un petit mur vertical.

Slab located above a small vertical wall. Traditionnelle jusqu'aux scellements.

Trad up to the anchors.

Varied and fun climbing. Stout for the grade? To the right of Diabloton. Find the vertical crack with a little block on the top left of it. Head up straight, wander left, wander right to follow the obvious undercling and then up to the anchors. Fixed anchors on top.

Trad lead possible, at least for the first half you might get a couple pieces in. But like the rest of the climbs on this part of the wall, you have nothing for the next 40 ft.

Crux is at the vertical start, though they are a variety of options (pull the overhang, or go left or right around it). The rest is an low angle moderate climbing to the top. Start at bottom level of the left section of the wall below a overhang. Follow funny cracks through or around the overhang, step to good stances, pull another little lip to more good stances. Wander left to pull another lip with face climbing to shared anchors with Le Nez or go straight up to follow a crack to anchors on a little higher up. Fixed glue-ins at the top. Shared with Le Nez, though you can use other bolts to the climbers right for TR as well.

Gear is good all through.

Ascend to a small roof, then climb left to a corner. Crack goes off-width at the end. 

Start left to "La Valse". Climb up to the small ledge.
Bring 1 rack with 3''+ to protect the end. Anchors on top

Getting the first 2m below you may be the crux! once you've passed the odd vertical crack, head up into the corner on your left and follow it (pin) to a large ledge (belay possible here). from the ledge, head straight up and a bit left of the belay (easy) or traverse diagonaly right passed a bolt and straight up to the top. found a couple loose holds at the beginning, be careful! Start at the obvious crack on the ledge right of the buttress.
Rap down, a 70m is more than enough to reach the bottom. Double rack to 1" + one C4 #4 or equivalent.
Belays and raps are bolted.

Start at the left of the ridge. After a few moves, traverse right towards the the ridge above the overhang. Commencez à gauche de l'arête. Suite à quelques mouvements, traverser vers la droite pour rejoindre l'arête après la partie surplombante. Further left route on the wall, right on the arete. Fixed bolts on top, sitting down a little father from the rest of the bolts. Shortest route on the wall. Fixed anchors at top.
Gear placement is good all the way up.

Suivre l'arête à partir du sol, passant par le petit surplomb. Follow the ridge from the ground up, through the overhang. Section la plus à gauche du mur, un mètre à la droite du dièdre sale.

Left-most section of the wall, one metre right of a dirty dihedral. Traditionnelle jusqu'au scellements.

Traditional up to anchors.

Direct start to Chico. Climb directly under and right of the dyke. Joins this large dyke a few meters from the top. Départ directe de Chico. Grimper directement sous et à la droite de la faille (dyke ou encore roche hypabissales). Rejoindre cette faille à quelques mètre du haut. Starts from the terrasse, right of an left angling ramp, aim for the short vertical crack midway up the wall.

Départ à partir de la terrasse, à la droite d'une rampe qui monte vers la gauche. Visez la fissure au millieu du mur. Trad up to the anchors.

Traditionnelle jusqu'aux scellements

Little crux at the start gaining the ledge. The rest of the climb is quite fun and varied climbing, excellent route to learn a variety of the techniques needed for climbing. Fun! Start on the left side of upper ledge of the belay area. Step up to ledge and follow left, straight up first few feet crack and then stay left of larger crack. Straight up and over dark colored blocky-looking section and wander a little left before making it up and over to the top. Fixed glue-in bolts at the top. Top rope access is easy following trail around the left of the buttress.

Gear is good for most of the way, a little sparse near the top-ish but you can definitely find the placements and all the stances are good. Excellent route to learn traditional climbing.

The left end (Chico) boasts an angled wall with plenty of options and tons of glue-in anchors for top-roping.
You can reach the top of the cliff by following a small trail (marked with blue arrows) on the left of the cliff with some glued in steps and fixed rope (not obvious with a child).

The right end (Valse) has some harder routes.
